column4: I have a number of computers on my network running ubuntu, I did a port scan of my network and found a number of ports I don't remember being open before. The ports aren't consistent between computers and none of them have a common application with any of these ports as default. Should I be concerned that my networked has been hacked?
what ports and what programs
http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/49918/ is my condensed version of the nmap scan where I only show affected computers and ports that I know I didn't open myself
paste the output of this command please    "netstat -apt"
Do you want that from every one of the affected computers?
umm just one with the ports open
Ok, http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/49919/ Let me know if you want more
ok you see where it says local address  616 that is port 616.  it is process PID 4677 and the program name is "rpc.mountd"
OK, should I be concerned? This computer has been up for 42 days; is there a way to tell when that process started?
ps -ef
or to just see that one  ps -ef | grep 4677
Apparently started on Nov 15. Any cause for concern?
it is NFS support listening for NFS connections.  did you install this, do you want it running?   http://linux.die.net/man/8/rpc.mountd
Must have. Thanks for your help. I'm going to go through the other computers to ease my mind.
run netstat to find out what program is using each port then just google it
I assume they're all the same thing; they all are running NFS. Thanks again
I might have spoken too soon. Here is the line from another computer from netstat -apt: tcp        0      0 *:1016                  *:*                     LISTEN     -
No PID listed
sudo netstat -evap | grep 1016
Scratch that *cue me feeling dumb*, I forgot to run it as root
It is, as expected, 4229/rpc.mountd
netstat is your friend
I really should get to know it better
